Question Text: $\text { I : }(p \Rightarrow q) \vee(q \Rightarrow p) \text { and II : }(\sim p) \Rightarrow(p \Rightarrow q)$@@@
Solution: \begin{tabular}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c}\hline$p$ & $\sim p$ & $q$ & $p \Rightarrow q$ & $q \Rightarrow p$ & $(p \Rightarrow q) \vee(q \Rightarrow p)$ & $(\sim p) \Rightarrow(p \Rightarrow q)$ \\\hline $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{F}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ \\$\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{F}$ & $\mathrm{F}$ & $\mathrm{F}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ \\$\mathrm{F}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{F}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ \\$\mathrm{F}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{F}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ & $\mathrm{T}$ \\\hline\end{tabular}

Question Text: Statement $\mathrm{I}$: $x^{2}+y^{2}=12$ and $y^{2}=4 x$ meet at $P$ and $Q$. Tangents drawn to $y^{2}=4 x$ at $P$ and $Q$ meet at $(-2,0)$Statement $\mathrm{II}$: Equation of chord of contact for a point $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ with respect to $y^{2}=4 a x$ is given by $y y_{1}=2 a\left(x+x_{1}\right)$@@@
Option 1: Statement$\mathrm{-I}$ is True, Statement$\mathrm{-II}$ is True and Statement$\mathrm{-II}$ is a correct explanation for Statement$\mathrm{-I}$.
Option 2: Statement$\mathrm{-I}$ is True, Statement$\mathrm{-II}$ is True and Statement$\mathrm{-II}$ is NOT a correct explanation for Statement$\mathrm{-I}$.
Option 3: Statement$\mathrm{-I}$ is True, Statement$\mathrm{-II}$ is False.
Option 4: Statement$\mathrm{-I}$ is False, Statement$\mathrm{-II}$ is True.
Solution: Statement-$\mathrm{II}$ is true.Also, solving $x^{2}+y^{2}=12$ and $y^{2}=4 x$ we get $P \equiv(2,2 \sqrt{2})$ and $Q \equiv(2,-2 \sqrt{2})$$\Rightarrow$ Equation of $\mathrm{PQ}$ is $x-2=0 \ldots \ldots(i)$Let $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ be the point of intersection of tangents then $\mathrm{PQ}$ has an equation $y y_{1}=2\left(x+x_{1}\right) \ldots \ldots(ii)$Comparing $(i)$ and $(ii)$ we get $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right) \equiv(-2,0)$$\Rightarrow$ Statement $\mathrm{I}$ is true and Statement-$\mathrm{II}$ explains Statement-$\mathrm{I}$ correctly.

Question Text: Two fixed points are $A(a, 0)$ and $B(-a, 0)$. If $\angle A-\angle B=\theta$, then the locus of point $C$ of triangle $A B C$ will be@@@
Solution: Given $\angle A-\angle B=\theta \Rightarrow \tan (A-B)=\tan \theta$$\Rightarrow \frac{\tan A-\tan B}{1+\tan A-\tan B}=\tan \theta$In right angled triangle $C D A \tan A=\frac{k}{a-h}$![original image](https://cdn.mathpix.com/snip/images/2hdzFFmE-El-04FZ3KbEl0bpbDejHocIOZizKJUeEwA.original.fullsize.png)Similarly in triangle $C D B$$\tan B=\frac{k}{a+h}$Substitute the values of $\tan A$ and $\tan B$ in (i), we get$h^{2}-k^{2}+2 h k \cot \theta=a^{2}$Hence the locus is $x^{2}-y^{2}+2 x y \cot \theta=a^{2}$

Question Text: The sum of $80$ terms of the series $11,102,1003, \ldots \ldots$ is:@@@
Solution: $11+102+1003+\ldots \ldots 80$ terms$\Rightarrow (10+100+1000+\ldots \ldots 80$ terms $)+(1+2+3+\ldots \ldots .80$ terms $)$$\Rightarrow \frac{10\left(10^{80}-1\right)}{9}+\frac{(80)(81)}{2} \quad \Rightarrow \frac{10^{81}-10}{9}+(40)(81) \Rightarrow \frac{1}{9}\left[10^{81}+29150\right]$

Question Text: The area above the $x$-axis enclosed by the curves $x^{2}-y^{2}=0$ and $x^{2}+y-2=0$ is@@@
Solution: ![original image](https://cdn.mathpix.com/snip/images/RAJs7mLIOE0dB9jVKz5jfrKRu_GQhYWjI1PT6F0AJH0.original.fullsize.png)We first draw the given curvesThe first curve $x^{2}-y^{2}=0 \Rightarrow y=\pm x$represents a pair of straight lines with slopes $1$ and $-1$ passing through origin. The second curve$\Rightarrow x^{2}+y-2=0 \Rightarrow x^{2}=-y+2$$\Rightarrow x^{2}=-(y-2)$represents a parabola with vertex $(0,2)$ axis as $y-$axis and concavity downwards. Both the curves are plotted in the figure and the required area is shown by the shaded region. The points $A$ and $C$ are the points of intersection of $y^{2}=x^{2}$ with $x^{2}+y-2=0$.Solving the two equations, we get $y^{2}+y-2=0$ [putting value of $x^{2}=y^{2}$ ]$\Rightarrow(y+2)(y-1)=0$giving $\mathbf{y}=-2$ and $1$, but $\mathbf{y}=-2$ is discarded as the required area is above the $x$-axis.$\therefore y=1 \Rightarrow x=\pm 1$The points $\mathrm{A}$ and $\mathrm{C}$ are respectively $(-1,1)$ and $(1,1)$ now due to symmetry Area of the bounded region $\mathrm{OABCO}$$=2 \times$ Area $\mathrm{OBCO}=2 \times \int_{0}^{1}\left[\left(2-\mathrm{x}^{2}\right)-\mathrm{x}\right] \mathrm{dx}$[Since $y=2-x^{2}$ is the upper curve and $y=x$ is the lower curve]$=2\left[2 x-\frac{x^{3}}{3}-\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right]_{0}=2\left[2-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{2}\right]=\frac{7}{3}$

Question Text: If a circles $x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}$ and the rectangular hyperbola $x y=c^{2}$ intersect in four points, $\left(c t_{r}, \frac{c}{t_{r}}\right), r=1,2,3,4$ then $t_{1} t_{2} t_{3} t_{4}$ is equal to@@@
Solution: Parametric equation of the hyperbola $x y=c^{2}$ is $(c t, c / t)$ and equation of circle is $x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2} \ldots(i)$ Put $x=c t$ and $y=c / t$ in $(i)$ $(c t)^{2}+\left(\frac{c}{t}\right)^{2}=a^{2}$ $c^{2} t^{4}+c^{2}-a^{2} t^{2}=0$From $(ii)$,$t_{1} t_{2} t_{3} t_{4}=\frac{c^{2}}{c^{2}}=1$

Question Text: The value of $a$ in order that $f(x)=\sin x-\cos x-a x+b$ decreases for all real values is given by@@@
Solution: We have; $\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})=\sin \mathrm{x}-\cos \mathrm{x}-\mathrm{ax}+\mathrm{b}$$\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=\cos x+\sin x-a$$\Rightarrow \mathrm{f}^{\prime}(\mathrm{x})<0 \forall \mathrm{x} \in \mathrm{R}$$\Rightarrow(\cos x+\sin x)$ As the max. value of $(\cos x+\sin x)$ is $\sqrt{2}$The above is possible when $a \geq \sqrt{2}$

Question Text: The centre of circle touching $Y$-axis at $(0,3)$ and making an intercept of $2$ units on positive $X$-axis is:@@@
Solution: From figure:![original image](https://cdn.mathpix.com/snip/images/-7ucN_ajUKwjYvtqRFkcmu7Ew4orBroWYWYeEh13gXE.original.fullsize.png)$r^{2}=3^{2}+1^{2}$$\Rightarrow r=\sqrt{10}$$\therefore$ Centre is $(\sqrt{10}, 3)$

Question Text: The value of the integral $\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{x}{1+\cos ^{2} x} d x$ is@@@
Solution: $I=\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{x}{1+\cos ^{2} x} d x=\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{\pi-x}{1+\cos ^{2}(\pi-x)} d x$$=\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{\pi-x}{1+\cos ^{2} x}$$=\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{\pi}{1+\cos ^{2} x} d x-\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{x}{1+\cos ^{2} x} d x=\pi \int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{d x}{1+\cos ^{2} x}-I$$2 \mathrm{I}=\pi \int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{1}{1+\cos ^{2} \mathrm{x}} \mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}=2 \pi \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{1}{1+\cos ^{2} \mathrm{x}} \mathrm{dx}$$=2 \pi \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\sec ^{2} x d x}{2+\tan ^{2} x} \quad$ Put $\tan x=t \Rightarrow \sec ^{2} x d x=d t$$21=2 \pi \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\mathrm{dt}}{2+\mathrm{t}^{2}}=2 \pi \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\tan ^{-1} \frac{\mathrm{t}}{\sqrt{2}}\right)_{0}^{\infty}$$=\sqrt{2} \pi\left[\tan ^{-1} \infty-\tan ^{-1} 0\right]=\sqrt{2} \pi\left[\frac{\pi}{2}-0\right]=\frac{\pi^{2}}{\sqrt{2}}$$\therefore \mathrm{I}=\frac{\pi^{2}}{2 \sqrt{2}}$

Question Text: $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n^{3}}\left[1^{2} \sin \frac{1}{n}+2^{2} \sin \frac{2}{n}+3^{2} \sin \frac{3}{n}+\ldots+n^{2} \sin \frac{n}{n}\right]$ equals@@@
Solution: $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum \frac{r^{2}}{n^{2}} \sin \frac{r}{n}=\int_{0}^{1} x^{2} \sin x d x$$\left[x^{2}(-\cos x)-2 x(-\sin x)+2 \cos x\right]_{0}^{1}$$=(-\cos 1+2 \sin 1+2 \cos 1)-2$$=\cos 1+2 \sin 1-2$

Question Text: India plays a series of $5$ cricket matches against Australia with $\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{3}$ and $\frac{1}{6}$ chances of winning, loosing and drawing each match. Result of one match is independent of the other. The probability of India winning a series with margin of $4$ wins or more is:@@@
Solution: Winning the series with margin of $4$ wins or more can be done when series finishes with a scoreline of $4-0$ or $5-0$ in favour of India.$\Rightarrow 5 \times\left(\frac{1}{2^{4}}\right) \times\left(\frac{1}{6}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2^{5}}\right)=\frac{1}{12}$

Question Text: The lines $\vec{r}=(2 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+4 \hat{k})+\lambda(3 \hat{i}+\alpha \hat{j}+4 \hat{k})$ and $\vec{r}=(3 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j}+5 \hat{k})+\mu(\hat{i}+\beta \hat{j}+\hat{k})$ are coplanar then :@@@
Solution: Clearly the given lines are neither coincident nor parallel. $\Rightarrow$ Lines are intersecting and$\left(\vec{a}_{2}-\vec{a}_{1}\right) \cdot\left(\vec{b}_{1} \times \vec{b}_{2}\right)=0$$\Rightarrow(\hat{i}+\hat{j}+\hat{k}) \cdot((3 \hat{i}+\alpha \hat{j}+4 \hat{k}) \times(\hat{i}+\beta \hat{j}+\hat{k}))=0 \Rightarrow(\hat{i}+\hat{j}+\hat{k}) \cdot((\alpha-4 \beta) \hat{i}+\hat{j}+(3 \beta-\alpha) \hat{k})=0$$\Rightarrow(\alpha-4 \beta)+1+(3 \beta-\alpha)=0 \Rightarrow \beta=1$$\therefore \alpha \in R, \beta=1$

Question Text: The value of expression $\sum_{r=1}^{n} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 r}{r^{4}+r^{2}+2}\right)$ is:@@@
Solution: $\sum_{r=1}^{n} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\left(r^{2}+r+1\right)-\left(r^{2}-r+1\right)}{1+\left(r^{2}+r+1\right)\left(r^{2}-r+1\right)}\right)$$\Rightarrow \sum_{r=1}^{n}\left(\tan ^{-1}\left(r^{2}+r+1\right)-\tan ^{-1}\left(r^{2}-r+1\right)\right)$$\Rightarrow \tan ^{-1}\left(n^{2}+n+1\right)-\tan ^{-1}(1)$$\Rightarrow \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{n^{2}+n+1-1}{1+n^{2}+n+1}\right)=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{n^{2}+n}{n^{2}+n+2}\right)$

Question Text: $f(x)=x^{2}+\int_{0}^{x} e^{-t} f(x-t) d t$, the angle between tangent to curve $y=f(x)$ at $x=-1$ and $+X$-axis is:@@@
Solution: $f(x)=x^{2}+\int_{0}^{x} e^{-(x-t)} f(x-(x-t)) d t \quad \Rightarrow f(x)=x^{2}+e^{-x} \int_{0}^{x} e^{t} f(t) d t$$\Rightarrow (f(x)) e^{x}=e^{x} x^{2}+\int_{0}^{x} e^{t} f(t) d t \quad \Rightarrow \left(f^{\prime}(x)+f(x)\right) e^{x}=2 x e^{x}+e^{x} x^{2}+e^{x} f(x)$$\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=x^{2}+2 x$$\Rightarrow$ Slope of tangent at $x=-1$ is $f^{\prime}(-1)=-1$$\therefore$ Angle between tangent and $\mathrm{+X-}$ axis is $\frac{3 \pi}{4}$

Question Text: If $x^{2}-2 x \cos \theta+1=0$ then the value of $\arg \left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)$ is:@@@
Solution: $x^{2}-2 x \cos \theta+1=0$$\Rightarrow x=e^{i \theta}$ or $e^{-i \theta}$$\Rightarrow \arg \left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)=\arg \left(\frac{1+e^{i \theta}}{1-e^{i \theta}}\right)=\arg \left(i \cot \frac{\theta}{2}\right)$$\Rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}$ or $\frac{3 \pi}{2}$

Question Text: Differential coefficient of $\tan ^{-1} \frac{2 x}{1-x^{2}}$ with respect to $\sin ^{-1} \frac{2 x}{1+x^{2}}$ will be@@@
Solution: Let $u=\tan ^{-1} \frac{2 x}{1-x^{2}} \quad \ldots \ldots$ (i)and $v=\sin ^{-1} \frac{2 x}{1+x^{2}} \quad \ldots \ldots$ (ii)In equation (i) put, $x=\tan \theta$$\therefore u=\tan ^{-1}\left[\frac{2 \tan \theta}{1-\tan ^{2} \theta}\right]=\tan ^{-1}(\tan 2 \theta)$$\Rightarrow u=2 \theta \Rightarrow \frac{d u}{d \theta}=2 \ldots \ldots (a)$In equation (ii), put $x=\tan \theta$$\therefore v=\sin ^{-1}\left[\frac{2 \tan \theta}{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}\right]=\sin ^{-1}(\sin 2 \theta)$$\Rightarrow v=2 \theta \Rightarrow \frac{d v}{d \theta}=2 \ldots \ldots \ldots (b)$From equations $(a)$ and $(b)$,$\frac{d u}{d v}=\frac{d u}{d \theta} \times \frac{d \theta}{d v}=2 \times \frac{1}{2}=1$$\therefore$ required differential coefficient will be $1$.

Question Text: $F_{n}(x)=\int(\log x)^{n} d x$ and $G_{n}(x)=F_{n}(x)+n F_{n-1}(x)$ the $G_{n}(x)$ is equal to : ($K$ is any real arbitrary constant)@@@
Solution: $F_{n}(x)=\int(\log x)^{n} d x$$\Rightarrow F_{n}(x)=x(\log (x))^{n}-n \int(\log x)^{n-1} d x+K$$\Rightarrow F_{n}(x)=x(\log x)^{n}-n F_{n-1}(x)+K$$\Rightarrow F_{n}(x)+n F_{n-1}(x)=x(\log x)^{n}+K$$\Rightarrow G_{n}(x)=x(\log x)^{n}+K$

Question Text: The value of $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} x^{m}(\log x)^{n}, m, n \in N$ is@@@
Solution: $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} x^{m}(\log x)^{n}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{(\log x)^{n}}{x^{-m}},\left(\frac{\infty}{\infty}\right.$ Form $)$$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{n(\log x)^{(n-1)} \frac{1}{x}}{-m x^{-m-1}} \quad$ [Using L-Hospital's rule]$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{n(\log x)^{(n-1)}}{-m x^{-m}},\left(\frac{\infty}{\infty}\right.$ Form $)$$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{n(n-1)(\log x)^{(n-2)} \frac{1}{x}}{(-m)^{2} x^{-m-1}}$[Again using L-Hospital's rule]$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{n(n-1)(\log x)^{n-2}}{m^{2} x^{-m}},\left(\frac{\infty}{\infty}\right.$ Form $)$![original image](https://cdn.mathpix.com/snip/images/B2GzNkh0yIFwbhJsg1ZcO-tVGuXUdSgiCuusH34o4ak.original.fullsize.png)$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{n !}{(-m)^{n} x^{-m}}=0$

Question Text: Exactly one root of cubic expression $x^{3}-12 x+5$ lie in :$\mathrm{III.}$ $(2, \infty)$@@@
Solution: NULL
column11: Let $f(x)=x^{3}-12 x+5$$f(-\infty) \rightarrow-\infty, f(\infty) \rightarrow \infty \quad ; \quad f(-2)=-8+24+5=21$ and $f(2)=8-24+5=-11$$\therefore$ Three distinct real roots lie in I, II and III

Question Text: In a $\Delta A B C, A D$ bisects angle $A$ and $D$ lies on $B C$. Length of $A D$ when $\overrightarrow{A B}=2 i+2 j+k$ and $\overrightarrow{A C}=3 i+4 k$ is:@@@
Solution: $|\overrightarrow{A B}|=3$ and $|\overrightarrow{A C}|=5$$\Rightarrow D \equiv\left(\frac{19}{8}, \frac{10}{8}, \frac{17}{8}\right)$$\left[\because \frac{A B}{A C}=\frac{B D}{D C}\right]$$|\overrightarrow{A D}|=\frac{5}{8} \sqrt{30} \quad[$ Let $A \equiv 0]$

Question Text: An ellipse in the first quadrant is tangent to co-ordinate axes. If one focus is $\mathrm{F}_{1}(3,7)$, and the other focus is $\mathrm{F}_{2}(\mathrm{~d}, 7)$, then the value of $\sqrt{3 d}$ is equal to@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (7)
Solution: We have $q_{1} q_{2}=3 d=b^{2}$and $p_{1} p_{2}=49=b^{2}$Hence $3 d=49 \Rightarrow \sqrt{3 d}=\sqrt{49}=7$![original image](https://cdn.mathpix.com/snip/images/HUxMcDYsHMUolrMh315cMRsTqtplYeP4aPK220zCxV0.original.fullsize.png)

Question Text: $A$ and $B$ are two sets comprising of $5$ and $2$ elements each. The number of unordered pair disjoint subsets of $A \times B$ having $5$ elements and $3$ elements respectively are :@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (2520)
Solution: Number of elements in $A \times B=10$. Number of disjoint subsets of $5$ elements and $3$ elements each are ${ }^{10} C_{5} \times{ }^{5} C_{3}=2520$

Question Text: For all complex numbers $z_{1}, z_{2}$ satisfying $\left|z_{1}\right|=12$ and $\left|z_{2}-3-4 i\right|=5$, the minimum value of $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|$ is@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (2)
Solution: We know that, $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right| \geq|| z_{1}|-| z_{2}|\ldots(i)$Here $\left|z_{1}\right|=12$ and $\left|z_{2}-3-4 i\right|=5$but $\left|z_{2}-(3+4 i)\right| \geq|| z_{2}|-| 3+4 i||$$\Rightarrow 5 \geq\left|z_{2}\right|-5$$\Rightarrow \left|z_{2}\right| \leq 10$Also from $(i)$ $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|$ will have least value when $\left|z_{2}\right|$ has greatest value i.e. $10$$\therefore \left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right| \geq 12-10=2$Thus min. value of $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|$ is $2$.

Question Text: $\sin ^{2} 12^{\circ}+\sin ^{2} 21^{\circ}+\sin ^{2} 39^{\circ}+\sin ^{2} 48^{\circ}-\sin ^{2} 9^{\circ}-\sin ^{2} 18^{\circ}$ is equal to@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (1)
Solution: we can write the given expression as$\sin ^{2} 12^{\circ}+\sin ^{2} 21^{\circ}+\left(\sin ^{2} 39^{\circ}-\sin ^{2} 9^{\circ}\right)+\left(\sin ^{2} 48^{\circ}-\sin ^{2} 18^{\circ}\right)$$=\sin ^{2} 12^{\circ}+\sin ^{2} 21^{\circ}+\sin \left(48^{\circ}\right) \sin \left(30^{\circ}\right)+\sin \left(66^{\circ}\right) \sin \left(30^{\circ}\right)$$=\sin ^{2} 12^{\circ}+\sin ^{2} 21^{\circ}+\frac{1}{2} \sin 48^{\circ}+\frac{1}{2} \sin 66^{\circ}$$=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\cos 24^{\circ}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\cos 42^{\circ}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \cos 42^{\circ}+\frac{1}{2} \cos 24^{\circ}$$=1$

Question Text: The value of $\operatorname{Lim}_{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\sum_{r=1}^{n}\left(\frac{2 r+5}{r^{2}+r}\right)\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{r+1}\right)$ is equal to@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (1.8)
Solution: $\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{r}}=\frac{5(\mathrm{r}+1)-3 \mathrm{r}}{\mathrm{r}(\mathrm{r}+1)} \cdot\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{\mathrm{r}+1}$$=\left(\frac{5}{\mathrm{r}}-\frac{3}{\mathrm{r}+1}\right)_{\mathrm{r}}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{\mathrm{r}+1}$$=\frac{5}{\mathrm{r}} \cdot \frac{3}{5} \cdot\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{\mathrm{r}}-\frac{3}{\mathrm{r}+1}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{\mathrm{r}+1}$$=3\left[\frac{1}{\mathrm{r}} \cdot\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)-\frac{1}{\mathrm{r}+1}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{\mathrm{r}+1}\right]$$\therefore \mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{n}}=\sum_{\mathrm{r}=1}^{\mathrm{n}} \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{r}}$$\mathrm{T}_{1}=3\left[\frac{1}{1}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{1}-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{2}\right]$$\mathrm{T}_{2}=3\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{3}\right]$$:$$\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{n}}=3\left[\frac{1}{\mathrm{n}}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{\mathrm{n}}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{n}+1}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{\mathrm{n}+1}\right]$$\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{n}}=3\left[\frac{3}{5}-\frac{1}{(\mathrm{n}+1)}\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{\mathrm{n}+1}\right]$$\therefore \operatorname{Lim}_{\mathrm{n} \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{n}}=\frac{9}{5}$

Question Text: Find the greatest angle of a triangle whose sides are $a, b, \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+a b}$@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (120)
Solution: As the greater side of a triangle has greater angle opposite to it.$\therefore$ The angle $($ say $C)$ opposite to $\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+a b}=c($ say $)$ is the greatest in this case. Now, $\cos \mathrm{C}=\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}}{2 a b}$$=\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}-\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+a b\right)}{2 a b} \quad\left[\because c^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}+a b\right]$$=\frac{-a b}{2 a b}=\frac{-1}{2} ; \mathrm{C}=120^{\circ}$

Question Text: If function $\mathrm{y}=f(\mathrm{x})$ satisfy the differential equation $\left(x^{3}+1\right) d y=x(1-3 x y) d x$ and $f(0)=0$, then $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{2}}{f(x)}$ is equal to@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (2)
Solution: $\left(x^{3}+1\right) d y+3 x^{2} y d x=x d x$$\Rightarrow y\left(x^{3}+1\right)=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+C$$\Rightarrow y=\frac{x^{2}}{2\left(x^{3}+1\right)}$$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 2\left(x^{3}+1\right)=2$

Question Text: Two roads $O A$ and $O B$ intersect at an angle of $60^{\circ}$. A car driver approaches $O$ from $A$ where $O A=800 \mathrm{~m}$ at a uniform speed of $20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$. Simultaneously another car moves from $O$ towards $B$ at a uniform speed of $25 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}$. If $t$ is the time when the two cars are closest. then $[t]^{2}$ is equal to $([\mathrm{x}]$ means greatest integer less than or equal to $\mathrm{x})$@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (256)
Solution: Let the distance between two cars after $t$ seconds be $\mathrm{s}$. Distance covered by first car in $t$ seconds is $20 t$, so its distance from $O$ will be $(800-20 t \mathrm{~m})$ and the distance covered by second car will be $25 t \mathrm{~m}$.$\frac{1}{2}=\cos 60^{\circ}=\frac{(800-20 t)^{2}+(25 t)^{2}-s^{2}}{(800-20 t) 25 t}$$\Rightarrow s^{2}=(800-20 t)^{2}+625 t^{2}-(40-t) 250 t$For $s$ to be minimum, we have $\frac{\mathrm{d} s}{\mathrm{~d} t}=0$$\Rightarrow-40(800-20 t)+1250 t-(40-t) 250+250 t=0$$\Rightarrow-42000+2550 t=0$$\Rightarrow t=\frac{840}{51} \sec$ so $[t]=16$

Question Text: Let $T$ and $D$ be number of triangles and diagonals formed by joining vertices of $n$-sided regular polygon respectively such that $T=D+5$, then the value of $n$ is:@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (5)

Question Text: $A$ and $B$ are coefficients of terms independent of $x$ in the expansions $\left(x^{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}\right)^{10}$ and $\left(\sqrt{x}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}\right)^{10}$. The ratio of $A$ and $B$ is:@@@
Error if any: No Options Found || Right Option not Found instead found : (1)
Solution: For $\left(x^{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}\right)^{10} ; T_{r+1}={ }^{10} C_{r}\left(x^{2}\right)^{10-r}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}\right)^{r}={ }^{10} C_{r} x^{\frac{40-5 r}{2}}$For $\left(\sqrt{x}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}\right)^{10} ; T_{r+1}={ }^{10} C_{r}\left(x^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{10-r}\left(x^{-2}\right)^{r}={ }^{10} C_{r}(x)^{\frac{10-5 r}{2}}$$\Rightarrow r=8$ and $r=2$ for terms independent of $x$ in two expansions respectively.$\Rightarrow A={ }^{10} C_{8}$ and $B={ }^{10} C_{2} \Rightarrow A: B=1: 1$
